questions.text: Identify
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Pseudoexfoliation Syndrome (PEX) is a systemic condition that primarily affects the eye. It is characterized by the accumulation of extracellular fibrillar material on the anterior lens capsule, pupillary margin, and other intraocular structures. Due to weak zonular fibers, it is associated with an increased risk of glaucoma (pseudoexfoliation glaucoma) and complications during cataract surgery Other options: A) Vossius ring is a ring-shaped pigment deposition on the anterior lens capsule, usually due to blunt trauma. It forms from iris pigment epithelial cells that are transferred onto the lens C) Foreign body: A retained intraocular foreign body would appear as a discrete object within the eye, often metallic or glass, rather than a diffuse flaky deposition D) Ocular trauma: Trauma can lead to various changes in the eye (e.g., Vossius ring, hyphae, lens dislocation), pseudoexfoliation is a degenerative condition unrelated to acute injury

questions.text: Which Vitamin deficiency cause this
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The given image shows Bitot’s spots. Bitot spots are foamy, keratinized plaques on the conjunctiva, often found bilaterally. They are caused by Vitamin A deficiency and are an early sign of xerophthalmia, which can progress to night blindness and corneal ulceration if untreated. Other options: B) Vitamin B – Various B-vitamin deficiencies cause neuropathy, anemia, and glossitis but not Bitot spots C) Vitamin C – Deficiency leads to scurvy, characterized by gum bleeding, poor wound healing, and bruising D) Vitamin D – Deficiency causes rickets (in children) and osteomalacia (in adults), affecting bone mineralization

questions.text: The procedure is done for?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Intracorneal Ring Segments (ICRS) are implanted in the corneal stroma to improve corneal shape and vision in patients with keratoconus Other options: A) Keratoglobus – A rare condition with generalized corneal thinning, usually not treated with ICRS but rather with protective measures or corneal graft C) Vogt's Limbal Girdle – An age-related benign degenerative change at the corneal periphery, not requiring ICRS D) Corneal Dystrophy – A group of inherited disorders affecting the cornea, often treated with corneal transplants or laser procedures, not ICRS

questions.text: A diabetic patient with 6/9 visual acuity in 1 eye with retinal hemorrageswith neovascularization at optic disc. What is the management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The presence of retinal hemorrhages and neovascularization of the optic disc (NVD) in a diabetic patient suggests proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR). Pan retinal photocoagulation (PRP) is the standard treatment to reduce the risk of vitreous hemorrhage and tractional retinal detachment Other options: A) Focal Laser Photocoagulation: Used for clinically significant macular edema (CSME) C) Grid Laser: Used for diffuse diabetic macular edema (DME) D) Scleral Buckling: Used for rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (RRD), not diabetic retinopathy

questions.text: Parents brought their child to the clinic where he was found to have mental retardation, skeletal muscle weakness and cherry red spot in retina. What could be the diagnosis among the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The child presents with mental retardation, skeletal muscle weakness, and cherry-red spots in the retina, which are characteristic features of Tay-Sachs disease, a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of hexosaminidase A Other options: B) Hurler Syndrome: caused by alpha-L-iduronidase deficiency, leading to mucopolysaccharide accumulation and clinical features include Gargoylism, corneal clouding, skeletal abnormalities, and hepatosplenomegaly C) Hunter Syndrome: Iduronate-2-sulfatase deficiency leads to mucopolysaccharide buildup. No corneal clouding and it is X-linked inheritance D) Gaucher Disease: Caused by glucocerebrosidase deficiency, leading to glucocerebroside accumulation in macrophages. Hepatosplenomegaly, bone pain, and anemia, but not cherry-red spots

questions.text: A middle aged female with Rheumatoid arthritis presents with the following slit lamp picture. What is the condition shown here?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ciliary staphyloma is a local bulging or outpouching of the sclera around the limbus, often associated with chronic inflammation, such as in rheumatoid arthritis. This condition typically results in a thinning of the scleral tissue that may form a conical shape or bulge Other options: A) Scleromalacia Perforans: Chronic scleral thinning leading to perforation, often in rheumatoid arthritis and characterized by progressive weakening of the sclera without noticeable inflammation, leading to risk of scleral perforation C) Melanoma: Malignant tumor originating from melanocytes and usually presents as pigmented lesion on the uveal tract, not associated with scleral bulging D) Tranta Dots: Small white dots at the limbus seen in allergic conjunctivitis and it is Indicative of eosinophilic infiltration rather than scleral changes

questions.text: Sympathetic ophthalmia would lead to?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Sympathetic ophthalmia is a rare bilateral granulomatous uveitis that occurs after penetrating trauma to one eye, leading to inflammation of all layers of both eyes. It typically presents with panuveitis, which involves inflammation of the anterior, posterior, and intermediate uveal structures of both eyes Other options: B) Acute Anterior Uveitis primarily affects the anterior segment of the eye, such as the iris and ciliary body. This is not characteristic of sympathetic ophthalmia, which involves inflammation of all layers of the eye. C) Chronic Anterior Uveitis is typically a persistent, low-grade inflammation of the anterior segment, but sympathetic ophthalmia causes a more acute and bilateral inflammation, not confined to the anterior segment D) Posterior Uveitis involves inflammation of the choroid and retina, which may be seen in other conditions but is not the predominant feature in sympathetic ophthalmia, where the inflammation is more diffuse, involving all layers

questions.text: Where is the likely lesion if patient cannot see right visual field images from both eyes?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The lesion in the left optic tract will cause loss of the right visual field in both eyes due to the crossed nature of visual information. The optic tract transmits visual information from the opposite visual field, so the left tract affects the right visual field of both eyes Other options: A) Left Occipital Lobe: A lesion in the left occipital lobe would affect the visual field in the right side, but it would cause homonymous hemianopia (loss of right visual field in both eyes), not specifically from the right visual field from both eyes. Visual fields are processed in the occipital cortex, but this would affect a larger area, including both eyes, in the same visual field C) Optic Chiasma: A lesion at the optic chiasma typically affects the nasal fibers from both optic nerves, resulting in bitemporal hemianopia (loss of vision from the outer half of both eyes), not the right visual field of both eyes D) Right Optic Nerve: A lesion in the right optic nerve would affect vision in the right eye and cause monocular blindness in that eye, but not a loss of the right visual field in both eyes

questions.text: A person has chisel injury while stone cutting. Which investigation is detrimental to diagnose?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In the case of a chisel injury from stone cutting, MRI is detrimental because it is not the most useful imaging technique to assess the type of injury commonly associated with such trauma. MRI is excellent for evaluating soft tissues like muscles, tendons, and ligaments, but it is less effective for detecting fractures, foreign bodies, or bony injuries, which are likely in this case. Chisel injuries from stone cutting often result in fractures or embedded foreign bodies, and MRI would not be the best tool to detect these types of injuries in the orbital area or skull. Moreover, MRI can be difficult to perform in the case of a foreign body, as metal objects (common in these injuries) may distort the MRI images or pose safety concerns due to magnetic fields. Why the other options are incorrect: A. X-ray orbit An X-ray of the orbit is a useful and appropriate investigation for diagnosing a chisel injury, especially if there is a suspicion of orbital bone fractures or foreign bodies. While an X-ray may not show soft tissue damage in detail, it is very good at detecting fractures and radiopaque foreign bodies in the orbit. For an injury like this, an X-ray is a standard first-line diagnostic tool. C. CT orbit A CT scan of the orbit is also appropriate for assessing trauma. CT scans provide excellent visualization of both bony and soft tissue structures, and they are particularly good at identifying fractures and the presence of foreign bodies (which is likely in this case due to the nature of the injury). A CT scan offers superior detail for bone-related trauma and can identify complications such as hemorrhage or fractures that may be missed on an X-ray. D. USG B scan While ultrasound (B scan) is less commonly used in orbital trauma cases, it can still be useful for detecting foreign bodies, particularly if they are located in the soft tissues of the eye or orbit. It is not as detailed as a CT scan for bony injuries, but it can provide valuable information, especially when a CT scan or X-ray is not immediately available. Hence, it is not completely detrimental and could still be employed in the diagnostic process.

questions.text: Most common complication of the following pic?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A coloboma is a congenital condition characterized by a defect or gap in the structure of the eye, often in the iris, retina, or optic disc. It results from an incomplete closure of the fetal fissure during eye development. The most common complication associated with coloboma is exposure keratopathy, especially when the coloboma involves the iris or lids Other options: B) Cataracts can be a potential complication in individuals with coloboma, especially if the lens is affected. However, cataract is not the most common complication compared to exposure keratopathy, which is more directly related to the eyelid and corneal protection C) Amblyopia can occur in cases of visual impairment due to coloboma, especially if the condition leads to significant visual defects or misalignment. However, it is less common than exposure keratopathy and typically results from abnormal vision development, which may not always be associated with coloboma D) Restricted Movements are generally associated with ocular motility disorders and are not a common complication of coloboma. Coloboma typically does not restrict the movement of the eyeball; it primarily affects the anatomical structure of the eye

questions.text: Which glycosaminoglycan maintains corneal transparency?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Keratan sulfate is the primary glycosaminoglycan (GAG) responsible for maintaining corneal transparency. It is found in the corneal stroma and helps to regulate collagen fibril spacing and hydration, ensuring light transmission without scattering Other Options: A) Heparan sulfate: Found in basement membranes and plays a role in cell signaling and vascular permeability, but it is not primarily involved in corneal transparency C) Hyaluronic acid: Found in the vitreous humor of the eye and is involved in joint lubrication and wound healing, but it does not contribute significantly to corneal transparency D) Chondroitin sulfate: Present in cartilage and connective tissue, providing structural support, but it does not play a major role in maintaining corneal transparency

questions.text: 15 year oldchild came with recent non acceptance of regular glasses for myopic astigmatism. What will be viable option?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In a 15-year-old child, LASIK, FemtoLASIK, and Implantable Collamer Lenses (ICL) are not viable options because refractive surgery is contraindicated in individuals under 18 years due to unstable refractive error. Spherical Equivalent Spectacles are the best choice when a patient does not accept their regular cylindrical correction for myopic astigmatism. This method involves averaging the spherical and cylindrical powers to reduce distortion and improve tolerance Other options: B) LASIK: Contraindicated in patients under 18 years as their refractive error is still changing. C) Femto LASIK: Similar to LASIK but uses a femtosecond laser for flap creation and not recommended for minors due to progressive myopia D) Implantable Collamer Lens (ICL): Used for high myopia but not recommended until refractive stability is confirmed, typically after 21 years of age

choices.text: Dot and blot hemorrhages, Diabetes mellitus

questions.text: The given sign is probably seen in which of the folowing?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hard exudates are lipid and protein deposits from leaking capillaries, commonly seen in diabetic retinopathy Other options: B) Soft exudates, Hypertension: Soft exudates (cotton wool spots) indicate retinal ischemia and are seen in hypertensive retinopathy and diabetes C) Flame-shaped hemorrhages, Hypertension: Flame hemorrhages result from ruptured superficial retinal capillaries, commonly associated with hypertension D) Dot and blot hemorrhages, Diabetes mellitus: These deeper retinal hemorrhages occur due to microaneurysms and capillary leakage in diabetic retinopathy

questions.text: A new bornchild with big blue eyes and watering. What will be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Congenital glaucoma is characterized by buphthalmos (enlarged eyes), corneal edema, excessive tearing, and photophobia due to increased intraocular pressure (IOP). The condition is caused by a developmental defect in the trabecular meshwork, leading to impaired aqueous humour drainage Other options: B) Mucopolysaccharidosis: This is a lysosomal storage disorder leading to corneal clouding, skeletal abnormalities, and mental retardation. It does not present with big blue eyes and excessive watering C) Cataract: Congenital cataract presents as lens opacification and leukocoria (white reflex in the eye), but it does not cause enlarged blue eyes or excessive tearing D) Ophthalmia neonatorum: A neonatal conjunctivitis caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Chlamydia trachomatis, or other infections, presenting with purulent discharge and swollen eyelids rather than big blue eyes and tearing

questions.text: A patient with history of contact lens use for 2 years now presents with irritation in eyes and sign as in pic. What is most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Giant Papillary Conjunctivitis (GPC) is common in contact lens wearers, prosthetic eye users, or those with ocular sutures. It is characterized by large cobblestone papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva, itching, discomfort, excessive mucus discharge, and intolerance to contact lenses and caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to mechanical irritation and protein deposits on contact lenses Other options: B) Follicular Conjunctivitis is characterized by small dome-shaped follicles on the conjunctiva, commonly due to viral infections (adenovirus), chlamydia, or chronic allergic reactions C) Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) is common in young males with seasonal allergic conjunctivitis, especially in warm climates. Giant cobblestone papillae are seen but associated with intense itching, ropy discharge, and photophobia D) Trachoma is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (serotypes A-C). It presents with follicular conjunctivitis, pannus formation (corneal neovascularization), and Herbert’s pits

questions.text: History of dryness, corneal softening, night blindness & gritty sensation. The above symptoms due to which vitamin deficiency?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Retinoic acid (Vitamin A) deficiency is associated with dryness of the conjunctiva (xerophthalmia), corneal softening (keratomalacia), and night blindness (nyctalopia). Vitamin A is crucial for the health of the corneal epithelium and the function of rods in the retina, which are responsible for vision in low light Other options: A) Iron: Iron deficiency primarily affects hemoglobin production and can lead to anemia, not symptoms like dryness, corneal softening, or night blindness B) Protein: Protein deficiency can lead to general malnutrition, growth retardation, and other systemic symptoms but is not specifically associated with eye dryness, corneal softening, or night blindness C) Niacin: Niacin deficiency causes pellagra, characterized by diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. It doesn't lead to eye dryness, corneal softening, or night blindness

questions.text: A child presented with U/L white pupillary reflex for which surgery was done. Biopsy of the surgical specimen showed flexnerwintersteinerrosette. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor of the retina and the most common cause of white pupillary reflex (leukocoria) in children. Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes are a histopathological feature of retinoblastoma, characterized by tumor cells arranged in a rosette-like pattern around a central lumen, resembling the normal structure of the retina Other options: B) Medulloblastoma is a malignant brain tumor typically found in the posterior fossa. It does not cause white pupillary reflex or show Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes in its histology C) Rhabdomyosarcoma is a soft tissue tumor, usually involving muscle tissue, and it does not exhibit Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes or cause a white pupillary reflex in children D) Astrocytoma is a glial cell tumor and is typically found in the brain or spinal cord. It does not present with white pupillary reflex or Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes

questions.text: Drug of choice for a patient of glaucoma with brochialasthma?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analogue used to treat glaucoma by lowering intraocular pressure (IOP). It is preferred in patients with bronchial asthma because it has minimal broncho-constrictive effects compared to other prostaglandin analogues and is safer for use in asthmatic individuals Other options: A) Gemoprost is a prostaglandin analog used for inducing abortion or for the treatment of intraocular pressure (IOP) but is not typically used in glaucoma with asthma patients due to its potential for causing bronchoconstriction C) Carboprost is a prostaglandin analog used for inducing abortion and for controlling postpartum hemorrhage. It can induce bronchospasm and should be avoided in asthma patients D) Alprostadil is used for erectile dysfunction and in neonatal ductus arteriosus closure, not for glaucoma management. It has vasodilatory effects but is not indicated for glaucoma, especially in asthma patients

questions.text: Most characteristic sign of fungal keratitis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Satellite lesions are characteristic of fungal keratitis, where small, round lesions form around the central corneal infection Other options: A) Dendrite: Dendritic ulcers are typically seen in herpes simplex keratitis, not fungal keratitis. It presents as a branching pattern on the cornea C) White hypopyon (a white layer of pus in the anterior chamber) can be seen in various infections, including bacterial keratitis and fungal keratitis, but it is not the most characteristic sign of fungal keratitis D) Ring abscess seen in acanthamoeba keratitis

questions.text: Which vitamin in high doses causes macular edema and macular cyst?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Niacin (Vitamin B3), when taken in high doses, is known to cause side effects like flushing, but it is also associated with macular edema and macular cysts, particularly in individuals receiving high doses for hyperlipidemia treatment. This can affect the retina and cause vision problems Other options: A) Vitamin A: High doses of vitamin A can cause toxicity and symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and blurry vision, but it is not typically associated with macular edema or macular cysts B) Vitamin D: Excessive vitamin D can lead to hypercalcemia, but it is not linked to macular edema or cyst formation in the eye C) Vitamin E: Vitamin E toxicity can cause symptoms like gastrointestinal discomfort and bleeding, but it does not cause macular edema or cysts

questions.text: Pre-requisite for sympathetic ophthalmitis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Sympathetic ophthalmia is a bilateral granulomatous uveitis that occurs after penetrating trauma or intraocular surgery, due to an autoimmune response against exposed ocular antigens Other options: B) Blunt ocular trauma: While blunt trauma can cause severe eye injuries, it does not typically expose intraocular antigens in a way that triggers sympathetic ophthalmia C) Chemical injury: Chemical burns primarily cause direct toxicity and inflammation but do not involve the immune-mediated response characteristic of sympathetic ophthalmia D) UTI: Urinary tract infections have no direct connection with sympathetic ophthalmia, which is an ocular immune response triggered by penetrating trauma

questions.text: Which layer of cornea helps in maintaining hydration of stroma of cornea?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The corneal endothelium contains Na?/K? ATPase pumps that actively pump excess fluid out of the stroma, maintaining corneal clarity and hydration. Other options: A) Descemet’s membrane: This is a basement membrane for the corneal endothelium but does not play a direct role in fluid regulation C) Epithelium: acts as a barrier to prevent excessive tear film absorption, it does not primarily regulate stromal hydration D) Stroma: The stroma consists of collagen and glycosaminoglycans that retain water, but it relies on the endothelium to prevent excessive hydration and maintain transparency.

questions.text: Extra set of eyelashes coming from posterior aspect of eyelid margin is known as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Extra set row of eye lash due to metaplasia of mebobian glands into eye lashes this is known as distichiasis

questions.text: A patient has u/l proptosis with b/l6th nerve palsy. What could be the possible cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cavernous sinus thrombosis: Causes bilateral cranial nerve palsies (commonly affecting CN VI first) and unilateral proptosis due to venous congestion. It results from infections spreading from the face Other options: B) Thyroid ophthalmopathy: Typically causes bilateral proptosis and does not cause cranial nerve palsies in early stages C) Retinoblastoma: Primarily affects children and presents with leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) and sometimes proptosis, but does not cause bilateral CN VI palsy D) Orbital pseudotumor: Causes painful proptosis but is typically unilateral and does not lead to bilateral CN VI palsy

questions.text: Shifting fluid sign is seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Exudative retinal detachment is characterized by fluid accumulation beneath the retina without retinal tears or breaks. The fluid accumulation can shift when the patient changes position, producing a shifting fluid sign Other options: A) Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is caused by a retinal tear or break, leading to fluid accumulation under the retina but does not specifically cause a shifting fluid sign B) Tractional retinal detachment occurs when fibrous tissue contracts on the retina, pulling it away. It is not typically associated with a shifting fluid sign D) Retinal dialysis is a type of retinal tear that typically does not cause the shifting fluid sign but can lead to retinal detachment

questions.text: Esotropia is most commonly associatedwith:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Esotropia (inward turning of the eye) is most commonly associated with hyperopia (farsightedness). In hyperopia, the eye tends to focus behind the retina, causing the eye to converge (turn inward) to compensate for the blurred vision, often leading to esotropia Other options: B) Myopia is typically associated with exotropia (outward turning of the eye), not esotropia C) Presbyopia is the age-related loss of accommodation and is not directly linked to esotropia D) Astigmatism can cause visual disturbances, it is not directly linked to esotropia

questions.text: Incongruous with Wernekieshemianopicpupil is seen in lesion of?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The incongruous Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is associated with a lesion in the optic tract. A lesion here causes a visual field defect that is not symmetrical (incongruous) in both eyes, as well as abnormal pupillary light reflexes (the Wernicke hemianopic pupil) Other options: B) Visual cortex: A lesion in the visual cortex can result in homonymous hemianopia but does not specifically lead to Wernicke's hemianopic pupil. The visual cortex processes visual information, and a lesion here can cause a visual field loss without direct effect on pupillary reflexes C) Optic radiation: Lesions in the optic radiation can also cause homonymous visual field defects, but the Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is more specifically linked to optic tract lesions D) Optic nerve: Damage to the optic nerve typically causes monocular visual field loss, not the incongruous visual field defect seen in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil

questions.text: A 65yrs old male with his of Diabetes and Hypertension presents to OPD with complaints of diplopia and squint. On examination secondary deviation is seen to be more than primary deviation. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In paralytic squint, one of the eye muscles is paralyzed, causing misalignment of the eyes. This results in a secondary deviation (the eye with the weaker muscle) being more pronounced than the primary deviation (the unaffected eye). Diplopia (double vision) is a common symptom in paralytic squint Other options: B) Incomitant squint can occur due to a variety of causes, including paralytic or restrictive causes, but it doesn’t typically describe the relationship between primary and secondary deviation. The secondary deviation being more pronounced is characteristic of paralytic squint C) Restrictive squint occurs due to physical restrictions (e.g., fibrosis or scarring of the muscles), limiting eye movement. While secondary deviation can also be more pronounced in restrictive squint, the most likely cause in this scenario with diabetes and hypertension is paralytic squint due to nerve involvement D) Pseudo squint refers to an apparent squint, often due to anatomical features like epicanthal folds or a wide nasal bridge. It doesn’t cause actual misalignment or diplopia, so the secondary deviation would not be more than the primary deviation

questions.text: In which nerve palsy, this action wound’tbe possible?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The third cranial nerve (oculomotor nerve) innervates the superior rectus, inferior rectus, medial rectus, and inferior oblique muscles. Levo-elevation requires superior rectus and inferior oblique to function properly. In oculomotor nerve palsy, both these muscles are affected, making this movement impossible Other options: B) 4th nerve palsy (Trochlear nerve palsy): Affects superior oblique, leading to vertical diplopia, but does not affect levo-elevation C) 6th nerve palsy (Abducens nerve palsy): Affects lateral rectus, causing difficulty in abduction but not in elevation D) 7th nerve palsy (Facial nerve palsy): Affects facial muscles, not extraocular muscles

questions.text: Middle aged women with B/L proptosis, with restricted ocular movements and chemosis, is eurothyroid. What is probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Thyroid ophthalmopathy: Most commonly seen in Graves' disease, with euthyroid or hyperthyroid status, but typically has painless bilateral proptosis and specific extraocular muscle involvement (muscle belly enlargement sparing the tendon) Other options: B) Orbital pseudotumor usually affects the tendon also C) Orbital cellulitis: Usually unilateral, presents with fever, acute onset, pain, and systemic signs of infection (e.g., sinusitis) D) Orbital lymphoma: Causes painless, slow-growing proptosis without inflammation, chemosis, or restricted movements

questions.text: Photostresstest is used to differentiate
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The photostress test is used to differentiate between macular disease and optic nerve disease by assessing the recovery time after exposure to bright light Other options: B) Retina and vitreous: The test does not differentiate between retinal and vitreous disorders C) Cataract and glaucoma: Cataracts affect lens opacity, and glaucoma is a disease of optic nerve damage; this test does not help differentiate them D) Cornea and lens lesions: Corneal and lens disorders affect refraction and transparency but are not evaluated by this test

questions.text: Drug decreasdIOP possibly by act on uveoscleral outflow
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analog that primarily works by increasing the uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor, which helps reduce intraocular pressure (IOP). It is one of the most commonly prescribed medications for glaucoma Other options: B) Timolol: Timolol is a beta-blocker that reduces IOP primarily by decreasing aqueous humor production, not by affecting uveoscleral outflow C) Pilocarpine: Pilocarpine is a miotic agent that works by increasing trabecular outflow, not uveoscleral outflow D) Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: These drugs reduce IOP by decreasing aqueous humor production, not by affecting outflow pathways

questions.text: A patient of chronic arthritis taking a drug developed difficulty in vision. On examination , no bulls eye findings of fundus observed. But later it was noticed that he was developing corneal pathology. What is the appropriate drug?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Chloroquine is an antimalarial drug often used to treat systemic lupus erythematosus or rheumatoid arthritis. One of the well-known side effects of chloroquine is corneal toxicity, which can lead to vision changes. This toxicity typically manifests as a corneal deposit or corneal pathology, which might not always present with the classic "bull's eye" maculopathy seen in other conditions, like hydroxychloroquine toxicity Other options: A) Sulfasalazine can cause some ocular side effects, such as dry eye or conjunctivitis, corneal pathology is not a typical side effect B) Leflunomide used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, is associated with liver toxicity and teratogenicity, but not with corneal toxicity C) Methotrexate can cause ocular toxicity (such as dry eye or retinal changes), but corneal pathology is not a common complication

questions.text: Identify the given instrument
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Maddox rod is an optical instrument used in ophthalmology to assess heterophoria or ocular alignment. It is typically used during a cover test to detect and measure strabismus or misalignment of the eyes. The rod consists of a series of parallel red or white cylindrical lenses, and it helps in detecting binocular vision issues by splitting the light entering the eye, creating a visual illusion that allows the examiner to assess eye movement and alignment. Other options: B) Maddox wing: This is another device used for measuring ocular alignment and detecting binocular vision problems, but it is a different method than the Maddox rod C) Maddox glass: This term isn't commonly used to describe an established instrument in clinical practice D) Red glasses: Red glasses are typically used for color vision testing or testing depth perception, not for assessing ocular alignment

questions.text: Identify the test as shown in the image
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The cover-uncover test is a clinical procedure used to detect heterophoria or strabismus (misalignment of the eyes). The test is typically performed by covering one eye while the patient focuses on a target. After uncovering the eye, the examiner observes any movement in the uncovered eye to detect misalignment. This test helps identify issues such as tropia (constant misalignment) or phoria (latent misalignment) Other options: B) Prism bar tests: These tests are used to measure the degree of ocular misalignment (strabismus) by placing different prisms in front of the eyes C) Pin hole test: This test is used to assess refractive error and determine if vision problems are due to refractive issues, such as nearsightedness or farsightedness

questions.text: Chemotherapy agents for retinoblastoma are
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The standard chemotherapy regimen for retinoblastoma includes a combination of • Vincristine (a microtubule inhibitor) • Carboplatin (a platinum-based alkylating agent) • Etoposide (a topoisomerase II inhibitor) Other options: B) Vinblastine, Etoposide, Bleomycin: This is more commonly used in Hodgkin's lymphoma, not retinoblastoma C) Vincristine, Vinblastine, Etoposide: Vinblastine is not typically used for retinoblastoma treatment D) Vincristine, Vinblastine, Cisplatin: Cisplatin is more common in germ cell tumors, and Vinblastine is not part of the standard retinoblastoma regimen

questions.text: Seton surgery is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Seton surgery refers to the use of a glaucoma drainage device (GDD) to facilitate aqueous humor drainage from the anterior chamber to an external reservoir, thereby lowering intraocular pressure (IOP). It is commonly used in refractory glaucoma cases where trabeculectomy has failed or is not suitable Other options: B) Trabeculectomy: A filtering surgery where a drainage fistula is created to allow aqueous humor to flow from the anterior chamber to the subconjunctival space. It does not involve an implant C) Trabeculotomy: A procedure that involves cutting the trabecular meshwork to improve aqueous outflow, commonly used in congenital glaucoma D) Goniotomy: A surgical procedure in congenital glaucoma where the trabecular meshwork is incised under gonioscopic guidance to enhance drainage

questions.text: Which is the most common ocular finding in myasthenia gravis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ptosis (drooping of the eyelid) is the most common ocular finding in myasthenia gravis (MG). It occurs due to weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (CN III). The ptosis in MG is typically variable and worsens with fatigue Other options: B) Lagophthalmos: Incomplete eyelid closure, usually seen in facial nerve palsy rather than MG C) Proptosis: Forward protrusion of the eye, commonly seen in thyroid eye disease, not MG D) Enophthalmos: Posterior displacement of the eye, seen in Horner's syndrome or orbital trauma, not MG

questions.text: Which of the following is decreased in retinitis pigmentosa?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is a group of inherited retinal degenerative diseases characterized by progressive photoreceptor loss (primarily rods, followed by cones). Studies have shown that Docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), an omega-3 fatty acid essential for retinal function, is significantly decreased in RP Other options: A) Arachidonic acid: A polyunsaturated fatty acid involved in inflammation but not primarily affected in RP B) Treilonic acid: This is not a recognized fatty acid C) Thromboxane: A lipid mediator involved in platelet aggregation and hemostasis, not directly related to RP

questions.text: Which of the following is against the rule correction astigmatism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Astigmatism is classified based on the orientation of the steepest corneal meridian • With-the-rule (WTR) astigmatism: Steepest meridian at 90° (vertical axis) ? Corrected with negative cylinder at 180° • Against-the-rule (ATR) astigmatism: Steepest meridian at 180° (horizontal axis) ? Corrected with negative cylinder at 90° -1.25 cyl 90°: This applies a negative cylinder at 90°, which is used to correct against-the-rule (ATR) astigmatism Other options: B) -2 spherical: Spherical correction applies equally in all meridians, not specific to astigmatism C) -3 cyl 180°: This applies a negative cylinder at 180°, which corrects with-the-rule (WTR) astigmatism D) +2 cyl 90°: This is a plus cylinder prescription, which is used in some cases but does not fit the standard rule-based correction

questions.text: A child has ptosis and poor levatorfunction. What is the surgery of choice?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ptosis with poor levator function (<4 mm) requires a frontalis suspension (fascia lata sling) procedure because the levator muscle is too weak to be effectively tightened or resected. Instead, the frontalis muscle is used to elevate the eyelid through a sling mechanism Other options: Levator muscle resection (Option A) is preferred for ptosis with moderate to good levator function Mullerectomy (Option B) and Fasanella-Servat procedure (Option C) are typically used for mild ptosis with good levator function and a good response to phenylephrine testing

questions.text: Mannitol is not given in which situation
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Mannitol is contraindicated in pulmonary edema because it is an osmotic diuretic that initially increases intravascular volume, which can worsen pulmonary congestion and fluid overload Other options: It is used in high intracranial hypertension (B) and cerebral edema (D) to reduce brain swelling by drawing fluid out of brain tissue into the bloodstream In drug poisoning (C), mannitol can be used to enhance renal excretion of toxins by inducing diuresis

questions.text: Which glaucoma drug is not given in children with sleep apnea
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Brimonidine (?2-adrenergic agonist) is contraindicated in children, especially those under 2 years of age, due to the risk of central nervous system (CNS) depression, lethargy, apnea, and even respiratory arrest Other options: Mannitol (A) is an osmotic diuretic used in acute angle-closure glaucoma but does not affect sleep apnea Pilocarpine (C) is a miotic agent that has no significant effect on respiration Acetazolamide (D) is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor and does not have CNS depressant effects that would worsen sleep apnea

choices.text: Decreased vision is due to astigmatism
Surgery is the treatment of choice
Infrared raysexposure is a risk factor

questions.text: True statement about given condition of eye are all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option D (infrared rays exposure as a risk factor) ? false as UV radiation (especially UV-B) is the primary risk factor, not infrared rays. Pterygium is more common in individuals with prolonged sun exposure Other options: Option A (mostly arise from nasal conjunctiva) ? true Option B (decreased vision due to astigmatism) ? true because the irregular surface of the pterygium induces astigmatism, leading to vision impairment Option C (surgery is the treatment of choice) ? true but only for cases with significant visual impairment or cosmetic concerns

questions.text: Most common cause of fungal orbital cellulitis in patient of diabetic ketoacidosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Mucormycosis (caused by Mucor species) is the most common cause of fungal orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). It is an opportunistic fungal infection that spreads rapidly through the sinuses into the orbit and brain, leading to rhinocerebral mucormycosis Other options: Aspergillus (A) is more commonly associated with chronic invasive sinusitis in immunocompromised patients but is not the most common cause in DKA Candida (C) usually causes systemic candidiasis and does not commonly present as orbital cellulitis Cryptococcus (D) is more associated with meningitis in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., HIV/AIDS)

questions.text: Most common orbital wall fractured in blow out fracture orbit is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The floor of the orbit is the most common site of fracture in blow-out fractures of the orbit Blow-out fractures typically occur when an object strikes the globe (eyeball), causing increased intraorbital pressure, which leads to a fracture of the thin walls of the orbit. The floor of the orbit is particularly susceptible because it is the thinnest of the orbital walls, and the forces from blunt trauma often cause the orbital contents (such as the inferior rectus) to push against it, leading to a "trapdoor" fracture Other options: Medial wall (A) is also commonly involved in orbital fractures, especially in cases of nasal trauma Lateral wall (B) and roof (D) fractures are less common in blow-out fractures compared to the floor

questions.text: What is the yoke muscle of right eye lateral rectus in dextroversion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In dextroversion (rightward gaze), the lateral rectus of the right eye contracts to move the eye to the right. The medial rectus of the left eye is the corresponding yoke muscle that works synergistically with the right eye's lateral rectus. This coordinated action allows for both eyes to move in the same direction Yoke muscles: In conjugate gaze (both eyes moving in the same direction), the yoke muscles are the muscles of the opposite eye that work together to produce coordinated eye movement For dextroversion, the lateral rectus of the right eye and medial rectus of the left eye are the yoke muscles In levoversion (leftward gaze), the medial rectus of the right eye and lateral rectus of the left eye are the corresponding yoke muscles

questions.text: 100 dayglaucoma is caused due to?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 100-day glaucoma refers to a form of secondary glaucoma that can occur after central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). It typically develops 2-4 months after CRVO, hence the term "100-day glaucoma." The condition is caused by neovascularization of the iris and anterior chamber angle, leading to elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) Other Options: B) Photolysis refers to the breakdown of a cataract and is typically not associated with secondary glaucoma in the way CRVO is C) Neovascularization in diabetes can lead to diabetic retinopathy and is a potential cause of neovascular glaucoma, but it is not referred to as 100-day glaucoma D) RD (Retinal Detachment) is not typically associated with 100-day glaucoma, though it may lead to other forms of ocular complications

questions.text: A diabetic patient came two days after cataract surgery with following presentation. He also has severe pain and redness in eyes. Which of the following is the first step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Given that the patient presents with severe pain, redness, and a history of recent cataract surgery, the most likely diagnosis is endophthalmitis, which is an infection inside the eye that can occur postoperatively. Endophthalmitis is a medical emergency and can lead to rapid vision loss if not treated promptly The first step in managing endophthalmitis is intravitreal antibiotics to control the infection and prevent further complications, such as vision loss. Broad-spectrum antibiotics are typically used for this purpose Other Options: B) Intravitreal steroids: These are generally used to reduce inflammation but are not effective in treating infection. In the presence of infection, steroids can worsen the condition C) Intravenous mannitol: Mannitol is used in cases of acute glaucoma or elevated intraocular pressure, not for treating infections like endophthalmitis D) Intravenous antibiotics: While systemic antibiotics may be used in some cases, intravitreal antibiotics are the mainstay of treatment for intraocular infections like endophthalmitis

questions.text: Third nerve palsy in diabetes mellitus presents with?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) In diabetic third nerve palsy, the most common presentation includes ptosis and ocular motility restriction, specifically in the movements of the affected eye. However, one of the key features of third nerve palsy in the context of diabetes is that it often spares the pupillary reflex. This is due to the fact that the fibers controlling the pupil (which are located on the outer aspect of the third cranial nerve) are often not involved in diabetic ischemic neuropathy. Therefore, pupillary reflex remains normal in many diabetic third nerve palsy cases Other Options: A) Pseudoptosis: This can occur in cases of diabetic third nerve palsy due to the weakness of the levator palpebrae muscle, but true ptosis is more commonly observed B) Proptosis: Proptosis (bulging of the eye) is typically associated with conditions such as thyroid eye disease or orbital tumors, not third nerve palsy C) Abnormal pupillary reflex: This would be more likely in compressive third nerve palsy (e.g., caused by an aneurysm or tumor), but in diabetic third nerve palsy, the pupillary reflex is usually spared

choices.text: Normal light reflex, accommodation reflex lost
Absent light reflex, accommodation reflex normal

questions.text: A 50-years-old patient presented with a history of STD and came to OPD with neurological abnormality. Which of the following is true?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The condition described seems to suggest neurosyphilis, particularly tabes dorsalis or general paresis of the insane. Neurosyphilis can cause a variety of neurological deficits, and one classic finding is Argyll Robertson pupils, which are small, irregular pupils that react abnormally to light but accommodate normally. This means that the light reflex is lost, but the accommodation reflex remains intact. Other Options: A) Normal light reflex and accommodation reflex lost: This is not typical for neurosyphilis or any related condition as in this case, the light reflex is typically absent but accommodation remains normal C) Both lost: Both light and accommodation reflexes would be lost in conditions affecting the parasympathetic pathway, such as in severe optic or oculomotor nerve lesions, not typical in neurosyphilis D) Both normal: This would be inconsistent with the findings in neurosyphilis, where light reflex abnormalities are characteristic

questions.text: A surgeon was doing strabismus surgery on a child, when there was a severe decrease in heart rate, what immediate step you will take to manage?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A severe decrease in heart rate (bradycardia) during strabismus surgery could indicate a vagal response due to ocular manipulation, which is known to cause significant vagal stimulation, leading to bradycardia. In this situation, the immediate step would be to stop the surgery to avoid further vagal stimulation, assess the patient's condition, and provide appropriate resuscitation if necessary Other Options: A) Lessen the plane of anesthesia: While reducing anesthetic depth can sometimes help in managing bradycardia, the first step should be stopping the surgery to prevent further vagal stimulation B) Atropine: Atropine is often used to treat bradycardia, but the immediate first step is stopping the surgery and assessing the situation. Atropine can be administered if bradycardia persists, but it's not the first immediate action in this scenario D) Glycopyrrolate: Glycopyrrolate, like atropine, can be used to treat bradycardia, but the first immediate action should be halting the surgery to prevent further vagal stimulus

questions.text: Which conjunctivitis results in blindness in neonates?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a serious cause of conjunctivitis in neonates, also known as gonococcal conjunctivitis. If left untreated, it can lead to severe complications, including corneal ulceration and permanent blindness. Neonatal gonococcal conjunctivitis is typically acquired during delivery from an infected mother Other Options: A) Chemical conjunctivitis: While common in neonates due to exposure to chemicals (e.g., silver nitrate used as a prophylactic agent), it does not typically lead to blindness and usually resolves with appropriate care B) Chlamydia: Chlamydial conjunctivitis can cause significant damage to the eyes and can lead to scarring and possible vision impairment if not treated, but it is less likely to cause immediate blindness compared to gonococcal infection D) Adenovirus: This can cause viral conjunctivitis, but it is not a major cause of blindness in neonates. Adenoviral conjunctivitis is usually self-limiting and does not result in permanent vision loss

questions.text: Which of the following enterovirus causes hemorrhagic conjunctivitis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Enterovirus 70 (EV70) is a well-known cause of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis (AHC), a highly contagious viral eye infection characterized by sudden onset of subconjunctival hemorrhage, pain, photophobia, and watery discharge. It spreads rapidly through direct contact and contaminated surfaces Other Options: B) E72, C) E69 – These are not known to cause hemorrhagic conjunctivitis D) E71 (Enterovirus 71) – While EV71 is associated with hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) and neurological complications, it is not a primary cause of hemorrhagic conjunctivitis

questions.text: Which neonatal conjunctivitis is most severe?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Neonatal conjunctivitis (ophthalmia neonatorum) caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the most severe form. It presents within 2-5 days of birth with profuse purulent discharge, severe eyelid edema, and corneal ulceration, which can rapidly progress to perforation and blindness if untreated. It requires urgent treatment with systemic and topical antibiotics (ceftriaxone or cefotaxime) Other Options: B) Chlamydia – More common but less severe than gonococcal conjunctivitis. Presents with mucopurulent discharge, but rarely leads to blindness C) Adenovirus – Causes a mild viral conjunctivitis that is self-limiting D) Chemical conjunctivitis – Caused by silver nitrate drops used for prophylaxis, presenting within 24 hours with mild redness and watery discharge, but resolves quickly without complications

choices.text: -2 D spherical and +1 cylindrical at 90 degree

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of simple myopic astigmatism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Simple Myopic Astigmatism occurs when one meridian is myopic while the other is emmetropic (i.e., one focus falls on the retina while the other falls in front of it) Option A (-2 D cylindrical at 90°): This indicates that one meridian has -2 D of myopia, while the perpendicular meridian has no refractive error (emmetropic) ? This fits the definition of simple myopic astigmatism Other Options: B (-2 D spherical and +1 cylindrical at 90°): This represents mixed astigmatism because one meridian is myopic (-2 D) and the other is hyperopic C (+2 D spherical and +1 cylindrical at 90°): This represents compound hyperopic astigmatism (both meridians are hyperopic) D (+2 D cylindrical at 180°): This represents simple hyperopic astigmatism (one meridian is hyperopic, and the other is emmetropic)

questions.text: A 25 years old diabetic patient presents with unilateral transient obscuration for 2-3 days followed by sudden diminution of vision. Which of the following test would you order?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A 25-year-old diabetic patient presenting with transient obscurations of vision followed by sudden diminution of vision suggests a vascular event, likely retinal vein occlusion (RVO) or ischemic optic neuropathy. Elevated serum homocysteine levels are associated with hypercoagulability, which increases the risk of retinal vascular occlusions in young diabetic patients. Other Options: B) Serum Creatinine Level: Checks for diabetic nephropathy but is not directly related to transient visual loss C) Serum ACE Levels: Elevated in sarcoidosis, which can cause optic neuropathy or uveitis, but does not typically present with transient obscuration of vision D) Quantiferon Gold TB Test: Used for latent tuberculosis, which is not a primary cause of transient vision loss in a diabetic patient

choices.text: More soluble protein, less insoluble protein
More insoluble protein, less soluble protein
Equal concentration of both soluble and insoluble proteins

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding concentration of proteins in senile cataract-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In senile cataract, the primary pathological change involves the accumulation of insoluble proteins in the lens fibers, which leads to the clouding of the lens. Over time, the lens proteins undergo aggregation and denaturation, causing a higher concentration of insoluble proteins Other Options: A) More soluble proteins and less insoluble proteins, as senile cataract is characterized by an increase in insoluble proteins, not soluble proteins C) Equal concentration of both soluble and insoluble proteins, as the balance is disturbed in cataracts with more insoluble proteins D) None of the above: Incorrect, as B is the correct answer

choices.text: Immature senile cataract and phacoemulsification with IOL.

questions.text: A 65 year old diabetic woman presents with painless loss of vision. The ocular findings are shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis and management for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Immature senile cataract is a common condition in elderly individuals, especially those with diabetes. The patient presents with painless vision loss, which is characteristic of cataracts, particularly when the lens opacity becomes significant. The management for immature senile cataract includes phacoemulsification with intraocular lens (IOL) implantation, which is the standard surgical procedure for cataract removal Other Options: A) Zonular cataract and lensectomy: Zonular cataracts are different from senile cataracts and typically involve the zonules of the lens. Lensectomy is not the first-line treatment, and zonular cataracts may not match this presentation B) Rosette cataract and sugar control: Rosette cataracts are characterized by a particular pattern of opacity that is not typical for diabetic patients with senile cataracts. Sugar control is important for overall health but would not be sufficient as a primary treatment for cataracts C) Sunflower cataract and lesion extraction: Sunflower cataracts are a specific type of cataract associated with Wilson's disease, not typical for diabetic patients. The treatment for these is different and focuses on addressing the underlying condition

questions.text: Which of the following refractive errors is associated with the image given below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sturm's Conoid refers to the visual pattern created when light rays from a point source focus at different points along two perpendicular meridians due to astigmatism. This occurs because the cornea or lens has an uneven curvature, causing the light entering the eye to focus on multiple points instead of a single point on the retina Astigmatism is the refractive error associated with Sturm's Conoid, where the eye's inability to focus light evenly causes distorted or blurred vision, especially at certain angles Other Options: A) Presbyopia ? Presbyopia is a condition related to age-related changes in the lens, resulting in difficulty focusing on near objects. It does not involve the creation of a conoid pattern and is unrelated to astigmatism C) Hypermetropia (Hyperopia) ? Hypermetropia or farsightedness is when distant objects are focused behind the retina due to the eye being too short or the cornea being too flat. It does not cause the Sturm's Conoid D) Myopia ? Myopia or nearsightedness is when close objects are focused in front of the retina. It is also not associated with the creation of Sturm's Conoid.

questions.text: A 5 year old boy presents with a small nodule on the sclera as shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Dermoid is a benign growth composed of skin-like tissue, including hair follicles, sebaceous glands, and sweat glands. These cysts are commonly located in the limbal area (the junction between the cornea and sclera) and can appear as yellowish, smooth, firm nodules on the sclera Other Options: A) Pterygium is a benign growth of conjunctival tissue that extends over the cornea, typically due to chronic irritation from UV exposure. It is usually triangular in shape, not a small nodule B) Pinguecula is a yellowish, raised lesion on the conjunctiva (usually near the cornea), often caused by UV exposure or aging. It is not typically a nodule on the sclera C) Dermolipoma is a rare, benign congenital lesion composed of adipose tissue, but it is less likely to present as a small nodule on the sclera compared to a dermoid cyst

questions.text: The eye examination of a 20 year old male shows a golden ring on the iris. What is the next investigation to diagnose the condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The golden-brown ring on the iris described in the question is a Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring, which is a hallmark of Wilson’s disease (hepatolenticular degeneration). Wilson’s disease is a disorder of copper metabolism due to a mutation in the ATP7B gene, leading to copper accumulation in the liver, brain, and cornea. The first-line investigation is serum ceruloplasmin, which is typically low in Wilson’s disease Other options: A) Alpha-1 antitrypsin: Used for alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, which presents with early-onset COPD and liver disease, not KF rings B) Alpha-fetoprotein: Marker for hepatocellular carcinoma and germ cell tumors, not Wilson’s disease C) Serum iron: Relevant for hemochromatosis, which causes bronze skin pigmentation, diabetes, and liver dysfunction, but not KF rings

choices.text: Fluorescein dye- visualised under green filter
Fluorescein dye- visualised under cobalt light filter

questions.text: What is the dye and filter used to diagnose corneal ulcers?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Viral corneal ulcers, such as herpetic keratitis, are best visualized using fluorescein dye and a cobalt blue filter. Fluorescein dye stains areas of epithelial damage, allowing dendritic or geographic ulcers (caused by HSV) to be identified. Cobalt blue light enhances the fluorescence of the dye, making the ulcer appear bright green Other Options: A) Lissamine dye - Green filter: Lissamine green stains devitalized conjunctival and corneal epithelial cells but is not the primary choice for corneal ulcers B) Lissamine dye - Cobalt blue filter: Lissamine does not fluoresce under cobalt blue light C) Fluorescein dye - Green filter: Green filters enhance contrast but do not cause fluorescence like cobalt blue light does

questions.text: An infant is brought with complaints of excessive watering of the eyes and photophobia. The image is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Congenital glaucoma is caused by impaired drainage of aqueous humor, leading to increased intraocular pressure (IOP) Classic Triad of Symptoms: • Epiphora • Photophobia • Blepharospasm Other Features in Advanced Cases: • Buphthalmos (Enlarged cornea due to increased IOP) • Corneal haziness • Optic nerve damage (if untreated, leading to vision loss) Other options: B) Congenital Cataract: Presents as painless leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) but does not cause excessive watering or photophobia C) Mucopolysaccharidosis: Can cause corneal clouding but is associated with skeletal deformities and developmental delay D) Ophthalmia Neonatorum: Neonatal conjunctivitis caused by bacterial infections (e.g., gonorrhea or chlamydia) but does not cause photophobia or buphthalmos

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient complains of decreased distant vision but now he does not use spectacles for near vision. What is this type of refractive error called?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Index Myopia occurs due to changes in the refractive index of the lens, commonly seen in age-related nuclear cataracts. As the lens becomes denser and more opaque, its ability to refract light increases, leading to improved near vision (myopia) but worsened distance vision Other options: B) Axial Myopia: Caused by an increase in the length of the eyeball, not lens changes. It is congenital or develops in childhood C) Curvatural Myopia: Due to an increase in corneal curvature, not due to lens sclerosis D) Positional Myopia: Caused by a change in lens position, which is rare and does not explain this case

questions.text: Which muscle is implicated in ptosis in Horner syndrome?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Horner syndrome is caused by sympathetic pathway disruption, leading to ptosis, miosis and anhidrosis. The Muller's muscle (superior tarsal muscle) is a smooth muscle innervated by the sympathetic nervous system. In Horner syndrome, loss of sympathetic tone results in mild ptosis Other options: A) Levator palpebrae superioris: The main eyelid elevator, but it is innervated by CN III (Oculomotor nerve). Its dysfunction causes complete ptosis (as seen in CN III palsy), not the mild ptosis of Horner syndrome C) Orbicularis oculi: This muscle is responsible for eye closure and is innervated by the facial nerve (CN VII), not the sympathetic system. Dysfunction causes incomplete eye closure (seen in Bell's palsy), not ptosis D) Horner muscle: There is no such muscle named "Horner muscle" in ocular anatomy.

questions.text: A patient interpreted a test like this?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The Worth 4-Dot Test is used to assess binocular vision, suppression, or diplopia by presenting four dots in red-green glasses • Normal Binocular Vision: Sees all 4 dots (2 green, 1 red, 1 mixed) • Right Eye Suppression: Sees only 3 green dots (left eye perceiving) • Left Eye Suppression: Sees only 2 red dots (right eye perceiving) • Diplopia (Double Vision): Sees 5 dots (crossed or uncrossed) Patient's Interpretation Suggests right Eye Suppression ? The patient sees only 3 green dots, meaning the right eye (red filter) is not perceiving the red dots Other options: A) Crossed Diplopia: Seen in exotropia, where the right eye sees the left image and vice versa. The patient would report 5 dots, not 3 C) Left Eye Suppression: Would see only 2 red dots, not 3 green dots D) Uncrossed Diplopia: Seen in esotropia, with 5 dots perception, not 3

questions.text: A patient presented after 3 years of cataract surgery with the given picture. What can be the condition ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The image and history suggest Elschnig’s pearls, which are clusters of proliferating lens epithelial cells left behind after cataract surgery. These migrate to the posterior capsule, causing posterior capsule opacification (PCO), the most common late complication of cataract surgery Other Options: A) Pseudophakic Bullous Keratopathy (PBK): Corneal decompensation due to endothelial cell loss, causing corneal edema and bullae, not posterior capsule changes C) Subluxation of Lens: Lens dislocation, often due to zonular weakness (e.g., Marfan’s, trauma), would not present with Elschnig’s pearls D) Corneal Dystrophy: Inherited progressive corneal disorders; does not present with posterior capsule changes

questions.text: A patient with nyctalopia presented to clinic. The following was seen. What can be the condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The triad of findings described are waxy pale optic disc, arteriolar attenuation and bony spicules along with nyctalopia (night blindness) is classical for Retinitis Pigmentosa (RP) Other Options: A) Retinitis punctata albescens – Also causes nyctalopia but shows multiple small white dots in the retina, not bony spicules C) Fundus Flavimaculatus – A form of Stargardt disease, presents with yellow-white pisciform flecks, not bony spicules D) Coats Disease – Characterized by retinal telangiectasia, aneurysms, and exudation, not nyctalopia or bony spicules

questions.text: Identity the lesion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A limbal dermoid is a benign, congenital choristoma (a mass of normal tissue in an abnormal location) that typically appears at the inferotemporal limbus of the eye. It is associated with Goldenhar syndrome (Oculo-Auriculo-Vertebral Dysplasia) Other options: B) Pyogenic Granuloma: Appears as a red, vascular, pedunculated lesion, usually occurring after trauma or surgery C) Pinguecula: A yellowish, slightly raised conjunctival lesion, usually near the nasal or temporal limbus, due to sun exposure D) Papilloma: A benign, pink, cauliflower-like lesion caused by HPV, typically on the conjunctiva or eyelid

choices.text: It is not seen in 10% pts with hyperthyroidism
NOSPECS score is used to classify
The management corresponds to improvement in thyrotoxic state
Visual loss is seen in some cases

questions.text: Which is false about the condition
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The management corresponds to improvement in thyrotoxic state: This statement is incorrect because Graves orbitopathy follows a separate course from the thyroid dysfunction. Although controlling hyperthyroidism is crucial, it can progress independently of thyroid function, meaning eye symptoms may persist or worsen despite treating the thyroid condition Other options: A) It is not seen in 10% of patients with hyperthyroidism: Graves orbitopathy is seen in 25-50% of Graves’ disease patients, not just 10%, making this statement true B) NOSPECS score is used to classify: NOSPECS classification is used to grade TED severity D) Visual loss is seen in some cases: Optic nerve compression (compressive optic neuropathy) due to swollen extraocular muscles can cause progressive vision loss, necessitating urgent management (steroids, orbital decompression)

questions.text: Which visual field defect is shown here
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The blind spot corresponds to the optic disc in the visual field, where there are no photoreceptors. An enlargement of the blind spot can occur due to conditions affecting the optic nerve head or surrounding retina, such as • Papilledema (optic disc swelling due to increased intracranial pressure) • Optic neuritis • Central serous chorioretinopathy • Peripapillary chorioretinal atrophy This finding is commonly observed on automated perimetry or Goldmann visual field testing Other options: A) Arcuate scotoma – Seen in glaucoma, it follows the nerve fiber layer and arches around the central vision C) Central scotoma – Seen in macular diseases, optic neuritis, or Leber’s hereditary optic neuropathy, causing a central field loss D) Seidel scotoma – An early glaucomatous defect, showing an upward extension from the blind spot

choices.text: Right saccade with left head tilt
Left saccade with right head tilt
Right pursuit with left head tilt
Left pursuit with right head tilt

questions.text: What is true for left side vestibular lesion
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A left-sided vestibular lesion leads to an imbalance in vestibular input, causing the brain to perceive a false sense of motion toward the right side Other options: B) Left saccade with right head tilt as the compensatory saccade occurs towards the unaffected (right) side C) Right pursuit with left head tilt: Pursuit movements are not a feature of vestibular compensation; they are smooth tracking movements controlled by the cortex, not the vestibular system D) Left pursuit with right head tilt incorrect for the same reason as option C

questions.text: Identify
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Homonymous hemianopia is characterized by loss of the same (homonymous) visual field in both eyes. It results from a lesion in the contralateral optic tract, lateral geniculate body, optic radiations, or occipital cortex Other options: A) Altitudinal Defect: Involves loss of either the superior or inferior half of the visual field in both eyes, typically seen in retinal artery occlusion or glaucoma C) Binasal Hemianopia: Loss of the nasal visual fields in both eyes, usually due to bilateral lateral compression of the optic chiasm (e.g., calcified internal carotid arteries) D) Bitemporal Hemianopia: Loss of the temporal visual fields in both eyes, commonly caused by optic chiasm compression (e.g., pituitary adenoma or craniopharyngioma)

questions.text: Identify
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Herbert pits • The image shows depressions or pits at the limbal region of the eye, arranged in a ring-like fashion. • These are Herbert pits, which are characteristic of trachoma. • They represent scars left behind by resolved follicles in the superior limbal conjunctiva. • Herbert pits are considered pathognomonic (diagnostically definitive) for chronic trachoma. Incorrect Options: A. Horner-Trantas dots • These are white, chalky dots made of eosinophils seen at the limbus. • Commonly found in vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC), usually associated with itching, photophobia, and thick ropy discharge. • These are elevated, not pits or depressions. C. Pannus • Pannus refers to superficial vascularization of the cornea, often starting superiorly. • Seen in trachoma, but it appears as blood vessels invading the cornea, not as limbal pits. • It causes corneal haze or opacity over time. D. Cobblestone appearance • Seen in vernal conjunctivitis, especially on the upper tarsal conjunctiva. • Refers to giant papillae, which are large, flat-topped, elevated lesions. • It is not a limbal finding and does not resemble pits.

questions.text: 2 month old child with the image. When is management
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Congenital cataract in a 2-month-old child, especially if it is unilateral and visually significant, should be operated as soon as possible to prevent amblyopia and permanent visual impairment Other Options: B) Surgery after 6 months: Too late; the critical period for vision development will be missed C) Surgery after 12 months: Unacceptable delay leading to irreversible amblyopia D) Medical management: No medical treatment can clear a cataract; surgery is the definitive treatment

questions.text: Intraocular mass with leukocoria, chromogranin ,synaptophysin +, Rosettes with scanty cytoplasm
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Retinoblastoma is the most common intraocular malignancy in children and typically presents with leukocoria (white pupillary reflex). Histopathology shows small round blue cells with scanty cytoplasm arranged in rosettes (Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes). Immunohistochemistry (IHC) markers chromogranin & Synaptophysin positive Other Options: A) Medulloblastoma – Found in the cerebellum, not intraocular; also forms Homer-Wright rosettes C) Optic Glioma – Associated with NF-1, presents with optic nerve thickening but not leukocoria D) Astrocytoma – Lacks neuroendocrine markers like chromogranin & synaptophysin

questions.text: Patient went to see a movie after that eye pain, circumcorneal redness, headache. On examination, there was dilated pupil. What's the 1st management
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The patient presents with acute onset eye pain, circumcorneal redness, headache, and a dilated pupil after being in a dark environment (such as a movie theatre). These are classic signs of Acute Angle-Closure Glaucoma (AACG) First-line Management of Acute Angle-Closure Glaucoma: • Mannitol (osmotic agent): Lowers intraocular pressure (IOP) by drawing fluid out of the eye • Pilocarpine (miotic agent): Induces pupillary constriction (miosis), which opens the angle and facilitates aqueous drainage Other options: B) Mannitol + Moxifloxacin – Moxifloxacin is an antibiotic, which is not useful in glaucoma C) Mannitol + Carboxymethylcellulose – Carboxymethylcellulose is an artificial tear and does not reduce IOP D) Mannitol + Atropine – Atropine is a mydriatic (dilates the pupil), which worsens angle closure and is contraindicated

questions.text: Sudden painful diminition of vision with difficulty to look into light for 2 days Visual acuity 6/12 on R eye, 6/60 on L eye Circumcorneal congestion
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The patient presents with sudden painful diminution of vision, photophobia (difficulty looking into light), and circumcorneal congestion (ciliary flush). These are classic features of acute anterior uveitis Other options: B) Acute Congestive Glaucoma would have severely reduced vision in the affected eye (counting fingers or worse) and associated with a mid-dilated fixed pupil and corneal edema (not mentioned here) C) Acute Conjunctivitis does not cause painful vision loss and usually presents with discharge, diffuse redness, and no circumcorneal congestion D) Scleritis is very painful but does not usually cause sudden vision loss. It presents with deep-seated boring pain, often radiating to the jaw/forehead

questions.text: A school teacher with irritation in eyes with and pinkish nodule which was resolved with drug and was recurrent. What could be diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Episcleritis presents as recurrent, mild eye irritation with pinkish nodules that resolve spontaneously or with topical drugs. It is commonly associated with autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis (RA) Other options: A) Scleritis (Rheumatoid Arthritis) is severely painful and does not resolve quickly with simple treatment. It causes deep red or bluish discoloration and is associated with severe RA C) Pinguecula is a small, yellowish, raised lesion on the conjunctiva due to UV exposure and dryness, but it does not cause recurrent pink nodules D) Pterygium (Astigmatism) is a triangular fibrovascular growth on the cornea, which can induce astigmatism but does not present as recurrent nodules

choices.text: Thyroid and orbit has same anitigen
The clinical features are not due to deposition of glycoaminoglycans
It is not related to HLA
Smoking does not worsen the condition

questions.text: Which is true about the condition
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Graves’ orbitopathy occurs due to autoantibodies targeting TSH receptors, which are also present in orbital fibroblasts, leading to inflammation and eye symptoms Other options: B) The clinical features are not due to deposition of GAG: Glycosaminoglycan (GAG) deposition in orbital tissues contributes to orbital swelling, proptosis, and eye movement restriction C) It is not related to HLA: Graves' disease is associated with HLA-DR3 and HLA-B8, indicating a genetic predisposition D) Smoking does not worsen the condition: Smoking significantly increases the risk and severity of thyroid eye disease in Graves' disease
